code: compute_ocidr <- function(dat) {   dat_cidr <- dat   dat_cidr[, 1] <- 100 * (log(dat[, 1]) - log(dat[1, 1]))   # Obs   for (j in 2:ncol(dat_cidr)) {     dat_cidr[, j] <- 100 *       (log(dat[, j]) - log(dat[nrow(dat_cidr), j - 1]))   }    dat_cidr }  SPYUS_ocidr <- compute_ocidr(SPYUS500)  plot_ocidr <- plot(dfts(SPYUS_ocidr),   val_axis_title = "", res_axis_title = "", FD_axis_title = "",   plot_title = "" ) set.seed(25641) spy_min_changes <- fchange(dfts(SPYUS_ocidr),   type = "segmentation",   statistic = "Tn",   critical = "simulation",   method = "characteristic" ) plot_ocidr <- plot(dfts(SPYUS_ocidr),   changes = spy_min_changes[[1]],   val_axis_title = "", res_axis_title = "", FD_axis_title = "",   plot_title = "", type = "fast" )

Given flexibility (pun intended) cubic-spline smoothing, often used default.  choosing basis, still must select KK coefficient vector ${\bf c}$ equation. typically done using least squares: choose ${\bf c}$ KK minimize $$\mbox{SSE}_{,K}({\bf c}) = \sum_{j=1}^{n_i}[X_i(t_{,j}) - {\bf c}^\top{\bf \Phi}(t_{,j})]^2.$$ K≥niK \ge n_i, sum squared errors can minimized $SSE_{,K}({\bf c})=0$, data “interpolated", .e. function X̂\hat{X}_i attains values observed data points ti,jt_{,j}. sometimes desirable, example raw functional data thought observed without additional observational error. cases though leads evident”overfitting". cases can make sense additionally penalize “complexity" ”roughness" function X̂\hat{X}_i. X_i(t) = \mu(t) + \sum_{j=1}^\infty \xi_{ij} v_j(t), \ \ \     \xi_{ij} = \langle X_i - \mu, v_j \rangle. scores ξij\xi_{ij} satisfy Eξij=0E\xi_{ij} = 0, Eξij2=λjE\xi_{ij}^2 = \lambda_j, E[ξijξij′]=0E[\xi_{ij}\xi_{ij^\prime}] = 0 j≠j′j\neq j^\prime. text: ARIMA models, seasonal versions, mainstay time series analysis since seminal work Box Jenkins (Box Jenkins 1970). models assume underlying scalar time series interest xtx_t essence linear function strong white noise sequence. Definition: say wtw_t, t∈ℤt\\mathbb{Z} strong white noise sequence mean zero, independent, identically distributed random variables finite variance. backshift operator denoted BB, defined Bjxt=xt−j,j≥0.B^jx_t = x_{t-j}, \;\; j\ge 0. Two guiding examples consider forecasting “strong white noise model", xt=μ+wt,\begin{aligned}     x_t = \mu + w_t, \end{aligned} ”random walk model" xt=μ0+tμ1+∑j=1twj.\begin{aligned}     x_t = \mu_0 + t \mu_1 + \sum_{j=1}^t w_j.  \end{aligned}. case first model, best predictor xnx_n given past values series mean value μ\mu, can estimated x1,...,xn−1x_1,...,x_{n-1} sample mean x‾\bar{x}. second model hand can rewritten xt=μ1+xt−1+wt⇔∇xt=xt−xt−1=(1−B)xt=μ1+wt,x_t = \mu_1 + x_{t-1} + w_t  \; \iff \; \nabla x_{t} =  x_t - x_{t-1} = (1-B)x_t=  \mu_1 + w_t, makes clear best forecast xnx_n based xn−1,...,x1x_{n-1},...,x_1 case xn−1+μ1x_{n-1} + \mu_1. second model also called “integrated model", since differenced values times series white noise can added (integrated) recover original series. ARIMA models essence choose two models also allowing additional serial correlation series. Given white noise sequence {wt,t∈ℤ}\{w_t\;,\; t\\mathbb{Z}\}, moving average process order qq (MA(qq)) form xt=wt+θ1Bwt+⋯+θqBqwt=θ(B)wt,x_t = w_t + \theta_1 B w_t + \cdots  + \theta_qB^q w_t = \theta(B)w_t, θ(x)=1+θ1x+⋯+θqxq.\theta(x) = 1 + \theta_1 x + \cdots +\theta_q x^q. AutoRegressive process order pp, denoted AR(p)AR(p), defined xt=ϕ1xt−1+⋯+ϕpxt−p+wt.x_t = \phi_1 x_{t-1} + \cdots + \phi_p x_{t-p} + w_t. define autoregressive polynomial ϕ(x)=1−ϕ1x−⋯−ϕpxp,\phi(x) = 1-\phi_1 x - \cdots - \phi_p x^p, AR(p) process characterized ϕ(B)xt=wt.\phi(B)x_t = w_t. ARMA (autoregressive moving average) model form ϕ(B)xt=θ(B)wt.\phi(B)x_t = \theta(B) w_t. Definition: xtx_t said follow SARIMA (Seasonal Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average) model orders pp, dd, qq, PP,DD,QQ seasonal period ss ΦP(Bs)ϕ(B)(1−Bs)D(1−B)dxt=Θ(Bs)θ(B)wt.\begin{aligned}            \Phi_P(B^s)\phi(B)(1-B^s)^D(1-B)^d x_t = \Theta(B^s)\theta(B)w_t. \end{aligned} abbreviated xt∼SARIMA(p,d,q)×(P,D,Q)sx_t \sim SARIMA(p,d,q)\times (P,D,Q)_s. seasonal period typically supplied practitioner often chosen match predominant “seasonality" ”periodicity" series. instance daily data s=7s=7 might used model weekly seasonality. typically achieved R specifying frequency parameter time series object. use function auto.arima forecast fpp2 packages R select fit models. function first selects differencing degrees DD dd via applying KPSS stationarity (Kwiatkowski et al. 1992) test time series xtx_t ∇xt\nabla x_t. text: Exponential smoothing introduced late 1950’s. basic principle behind exponential smoothing time series x1,...,xnx_1,...,x_n, two extreme forecasts x̂n+1=xn→ random walk prediction \hat{x}_{n+1}  = x_n  \;\; \longrightarrow \mbox{ random walk prediction } x̂n+1=x‾=∑j=1n1nxj→ iid noise prediction. \hat{x}_{n+1}  =\bar{x}= \sum_{j=1}^{n}  \frac{1}{n} x_j \;\; \longrightarrow \mbox{ iid noise prediction. } notice forecasts weighted linear combinations past values series x1,...,xnx_1,...,x_n: random walk model puts full weight xnx_n, whereas iid noise model puts even weights 1/n1/n value. general time series optimal prediction might fall extremes. Exponential smoothing models generally suppose weights decay geometrically.Simple Exponential Smoothing: forecast xnx_n x̂n+1=αxn+α(1−α)xn−1+α(1−α)2xn−2+⋯\hat{x}_{n+1} = \alpha x_n + \alpha (1-\alpha)x_{n-1} + \alpha(1-\alpha)^2 x_{n-2} + \cdots0≤α≤10 \le \alpha \le 1. prediction may restated :  Forecast Equation x̂n+1=ℓn Smoothing Equation ℓn=αxn+(1−α)ℓn−1=ℓn(α,ℓ0) Initial Condition ℓ0\begin{aligned}     \mbox{ Forecast Equation }& \quad   \hat{x}_{n+1}   = \ell_n \\     \mbox{ Smoothing Equation  }&   \quad \ell_n   = \alpha x_n + (1-\alpha)\ell_{n-1} =\ell_n(\alpha,\ell_0) \\     \mbox{ Initial Condition  }&   \quad \ell_0 \end{aligned} α\alpha ℓ0\ell_0 scalar parameters defining prediction, can estimated via least squares: (α̂,ℓ̂0)=argmin0≤≤1,l0∑=2n(xi−ℓi(,l0))2(\hat{\alpha},\hat{\ell}_0) = \arg\min_{0\le \le 1, l_0} \sum_{=2}^{n}(x_i - \ell_i(,l_0))^2 Linear Trend Exponential Smoothing: order make forecast mm steps ahead, extrapolate trend linearly follows: Forecast equationx̂n+m=ℓn+mbnLevel equationℓn=αxn+(1−α)(ℓn−1+bn−1)Trend/Slope equationbn=β(ℓn−ℓn−1)+(1−β)bn−1,\begin{aligned}       \text{Forecast equation}&& \hat{x}_{n+m} &= \ell_{n} + mb_{n} \\     \text{Level equation}   && \ell_{n}       &= \alpha x_{n} + (1 - \alpha)(\ell_{n-1} + b_{n-1})\\       \text{Trend/Slope equation}   && b_{n}          &= \beta(\ell_{n} - \ell_{n-1}) + (1 -\beta)b_{n-1}, \end{aligned} Scalar Parameters: α,β,ℓ0,b0\alpha,\beta, \ell_0,b_0 can estimated using least squares. Trend+Seasonal Exponential Smoothing (Holt-Winters ES): time series exhibits seasonality period pp, incorporate forecast follows. Letting k=⌊(m−1)/p⌋k=\lfloor (m-1)/p \rfloor, Forecast equationx̂n+m=ℓn+mbn+sn+m−p(k+1)Level equationℓn=α(xn−sn−p)+(1−α)(ℓn−1+bn−1)Trend equationbn=β(ℓn−ℓn−1)+(1−β)bn−1Seasonal equationsn=γ(xn−ℓn−1−bn−1)+(1−γ)sn−p,\begin{aligned}     \text{Forecast equation} && \hat{x}_{n+m}  &= \ell_{n} + mb_{n} + s_{n+m-p(k+1)} \\     \text{Level equation}&&  \ell_{n} &= \alpha(x_{n} - s_{n-p}) + (1 - \alpha)(\ell_{n-1} + b_{n-1})\\     \text{Trend equation}&&  b_{n} &= \beta(\ell_{n} - \ell_{n-1}) + (1 - \beta)b_{n-1}\\     \text{Seasonal equation}&&  s_{n} &= \gamma (x_{n}-\ell_{n-1}-b_{n-1}) + (1-\gamma)s_{n-p}, \end{aligned} Scalar Parameters: α,β,γ,ℓ0,b0,s0,...,s−p+1\alpha,\beta,\gamma, \ell_0,b_0,s_0,...,s_{-p+1} can estimated using least squares. note models may rewritten called “state-space" ”innovations" form. example, simple exponential smoothing model may rewritten : Observation equationxt=ℓt−1+εtState equationℓt=ℓt−1+αεt,\begin{aligned}     \text{Observation equation} && x_t &= \ell_{t-1} + \varepsilon_t \\     \text{State equation} &&  \ell_t&=\ell_{t-1}+\alpha \varepsilon_t, \end{aligned} εt\varepsilon_t innovation sequence representing residuals xt−ℓt−1x_t - \ell_{t-1}. assuming instance residuals Gaussian, one can easily simulate future values series xT+h(b)x_{T+h}^{(b)} well conduct model selection using information criteria AIC. ets() function fpp2 package R fits exponential smoothing models using least squares conducting model selection standard, linear trend, seasonal/Holt-Winters models using AIC. note function also chooses among “multiplicative seasonality" versions models. multiplicative Holt-Winters model non-negative time series can appropriate seasonal/periodic fluctuations series increase (decrease) function level series.

text: useful tool choosing models use time series cross-validation. Suppose wish evaluate quality model choice gg. example, might wish compare SARIMA Exponential smoothing produce forecasts. proceed follows: Select training, validation, testing ranges, 1≤tr≤v≤test≤T1 \le tr \le v \le test \le T, e.g. (70%,15%,15%)(70\%,15\%,15\%) data. Note: forecasting applications often forego testing set just use training validation sets. j∈{tr,...,v}j \\{tr,...,v\}, forecast X̂j+1\hat{X}_{j+1} based curves X1,...,XjX_1,...,X_j using model gg, interested horizon hh forecasting forecast X̂j+1,...,X̂j+h\hat{X}_{j+1},...,\hat{X}_{j+h}. Calculate losses Lj(g)=∫01[Xj(t)−X̂j(t)]2dt,L_j(g) =  \int_0^1 [X_j(t) - \hat{X}_j(t)]^2 dt, Lj(g)=∑ℓ=1h∫01[Xj+ℓ(t)−X̂j+ℓ(t)]2dt.L_j(g) =  \sum_{\ell =1 }^h \int_0^1 [X_{j+\ell}(t) - \hat{X}_{j+\ell}(t)]^2 dt. CV loss score model gg can taken CV(g)=1(v−tr)∑j=tr+1vLj(g).CV(g) = \frac{1}{(v-tr)}\sum_{j=tr+1}^{v}L_j(g). Small values CV(g)CV(g) suggest better performance. type time series cross-validation often called “expanding window" cross-validation, since forecast XjX_j stage using previous data X1,...,XjX_1,...,X_j. schematic works shown Figure 2.1.

title: functionaldata
text: Suppose goal forecast electricity prices shown previously next month. natural assume data weekly seasonality due typical work schedule. Using PCA discussed Section 1, 77 PCs can used explain 99% variation data. Figures show forecasts first two PCs entire electricity data using ets arima Hyndman-Ullah models. Although differentiating models visualizing difficult, one-step CV one last 20% data gives MSE estimates approximately 2280 (ets) 2522 (arima), suggesting use ets model gives 10% improvement. may also make sense transform data. can done manually using currently development parameter transformation shown . Running CV log sqrt root data, returns following results: 1.000 (fets), 1.106 (farima), 1.460 (log fets), 1.367 (log farima), 1.119 (sqrt fets), 1.153 (sqrt fets).
code: elec_ets <- projection_model(   X = electricity, forecast.model = "ets", TVE = 0.99,   n.ahead = 14, check.cp = F, alpha = 0.05,   sim.bounds = TRUE, M = 1000 ) elec_arima <- projection_model(   X = electricity, forecast.model = "arima", TVE = 0.99,   n.ahead = 14, check.cp = F, alpha = 0.05,   sim.bounds = TRUE, M = 1000 )  # CV pred_idx <- floor(0.8 * ncol(electricity) + 1):ncol(electricity) errors <- matrix(NA, nrow = length(pred_idx), ncol = 2) colnames(errors) <- c("fets", "farima")  cat("CV (", length(pred_idx), "):") for (i in 1:length(pred_idx)) {   cat(i, ", ")   idx <- pred_idx[i]   tmp_dat <- electricity[, 1:(idx - 1)]   tmp_dat$season <- 7   tmp_pred <- electricity[idx]   tmp_pred$season <- 7    pm1 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "ets", n.ahead = 1,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F   )   pm2 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = 1,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F   )    ests <- data.frame(     "fets" = as.numeric(       pm1$data$component_true$data[, idx]     ),     "farima" = as.numeric(       pm2$data$component_true$data[, idx]     )   )    errors[i, ] <- colSums((ests - tmp_pred$data)^2) }  colMeans(errors) / min(colMeans(errors)) #  fets  farima # 1.000  1.106 elec_ets$plots$components$`Component 1` elec_ets$plots$components$`Component 2` elec_ets$plots$forecast_plot elec_arima$plots$components$`Component 1` elec_arima$plots$components$`Component 2` elec_arima$plots$forecast_plot fit <- projection_model(electricity, check.cp = FALSE, n.ahead = 14) fit_log <- projection_model(electricity,   transformation = "log", check.cp = FALSE,   n.ahead = 14 ) fit_sqrt <- projection_model(electricity,   transformation = "sqrt", check.cp = FALSE,   n.ahead = 14 ) # With fitted data fit$plots$fit_plot fit_log$plots$fit_plot fit_sqrt$plots$fit_plot  # With original data fit$plots$forecast_plot fit_log$plots$forecast_plot fit_sqrt$plots$forecast_plot # CV with all pred_idx <- floor(0.8 * ncol(electricity) + 1):ncol(electricity) errors <- matrix(NA, nrow = length(pred_idx), ncol = 6) colnames(errors) <- c("fets", "farima", "fetsLog", "farimaLog", "fetsSqrt", "farimaSqrt")  cat("CV (", length(pred_idx), "):") for (i in 1:length(pred_idx)) {   cat(i, ", ")   idx <- pred_idx[i]   tmp_dat <- electricity[, 1:(idx - 1)]   tmp_dat$season <- 7   tmp_pred <- electricity[idx]   tmp_pred$season <- 7    pm1 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "ets", n.ahead = 1,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F   )   pm2 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = 1,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F   )   pm3 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "ets", n.ahead = 1,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F, transformation = "log"   )   pm4 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = 1,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F, transformation = "log"   )   pm5 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "ets", n.ahead = 1,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F, transformation = "sqrt"   )   pm6 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = 1,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F, transformation = "sqrt"   )    ests <- data.frame(     "fets" = as.numeric(       pm1$data$component_true$data[, idx]     ),     "farima" = as.numeric(       pm2$data$component_true$data[, idx]     ),     "fetsLog" = as.numeric(       pm3$data$component_true$data[, idx]     ),     "farimaLog" = as.numeric(       pm4$data$component_true$data[, idx]     ),     "fetsSqrt" = as.numeric(       pm5$data$component_true$data[, idx]     ),     "farimaSqrt" = as.numeric(       pm6$data$component_true$data[, idx]     )   )    errors[i, ] <- colSums((ests - tmp_pred$data)^2) } colMeans(errors) / min(colMeans(errors)) #   fets   farima  fetsLog  farimaLog   fetsSqrt farimaSqrt #  1.000   1.106   1.460    1.367       1.119     1.153

text: Consider pollution data. time compare functional approach traditional methods. CV 77 day forecasts used. Scaled CV results : 1.101 (arima), 2.453 (ets), 1.450 (fets), 1.000 (farima), 1.271 (log fets), 1.031 (log arima). case, know true errors. forecasting comparing truth next week, similar results seen: 1.376 (arima), 1.601 (ets), 1.450 (fets), 1.000 (farima), 1.866 (log fets), 1.073 (log arima). clear arima models better choices ets pollution.
code: # Forecast horizon: 7 days * 48 half hours = 336 pts h <- 7  # CV pred_idx <- ncol(city_dfts) - 13:7 errors <- matrix(NA, nrow = length(pred_idx), ncol = 6) colnames(errors) <- c("arima", "ets", "fets", "farima", "fets_log", "farima_log")  cat("CV (", length(pred_idx), "):") for (i in 1:length(pred_idx)) {   cat(i, ", ")   tmp_dat <- city_dfts[, 1:pred_idx[i]]   tmp_dat$season <- 7   tmp_scalar <- ts(as.vector(tmp_dat$data), frequency = 7)   tmp_pred <- city_dfts[, pred_idx[i] + 1:7]    scalar_arima <- forecast::auto.arima(tmp_scalar)   arima_for <- forecast::forecast(scalar_arima, h = h * 48, level = 95)   scalar_ets <- forecast::ets(tmp_scalar)   ets_for <- forecast::forecast(scalar_ets, h = h * 48, level = 95)    pm1 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "ets", n.ahead = h,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F   )   pm2 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = h,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F   )   pm3 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "ets", n.ahead = h,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F, transformation = "log"   )   pm4 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = h,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F, transformation = "log"   )    ests <- data.frame(     "arima" = arima_for$mean,     "ets" = ets_for$mean,     "fets" = as.numeric(       pm1$data$component_true$data[, (ncol(tmp_dat) + 1):ncol(pm1$data$component_true)]     ),     "farima" = as.numeric(       pm2$data$component_true$data[, (ncol(tmp_dat) + 1):ncol(pm2$data$component_true)]     ),     "fetsL" = as.numeric(       pm3$data$component_true$data[, (ncol(tmp_dat) + 1):ncol(pm3$data$component_true)]     ),     "farimaL" = as.numeric(       pm4$data$component_true$data[, (ncol(tmp_dat) + 1):ncol(pm4$data$component_true)]     )   )    errors[i, ] <- colSums((ests - as.vector(tmp_pred$data))^2) } colMeans(errors) / min(colMeans(errors)) #  arima   ets    fets  farima  fets_log  farima_log #  1.101  2.453  1.196  1.000   1.271     1.031 # Results tmp_scalar <- ts(as.vector(city_dfts$data), frequency = 7)  scalar_arima <- forecast::auto.arima(tmp_scalar) arima_for <- forecast::forecast(scalar_arima, h = h * 48, level = 95) scalar_ets <- forecast::ets(tmp_scalar) ets_for <- forecast::forecast(scalar_ets, h = h * 48, level = 95)  pm1 <- projection_model(city_dfts,   forecast.model = "ets", n.ahead = h,   check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F ) pm2 <- projection_model(city_dfts,   forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = h,   check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F ) pm3 <- projection_model(city_dfts,   forecast.model = "ets", n.ahead = h,   check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F, transformation = "log" ) pm4 <- projection_model(city_dfts,   forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = h,   check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F, transformation = "log" )  ests_final <- data.frame(   "arima" = arima_for$mean,   "ets" = ets_for$mean,   "fets" = as.numeric(     pm1$data$component_true$data[, (ncol(city_dfts) + 1):ncol(pm1$data$component_true)]   ),   "farima" = as.numeric(     pm2$data$component_true$data[, (ncol(city_dfts) + 1):ncol(pm2$data$component_true)]   ),   "fets7" = as.numeric(     pm3$data$component_true$data[, (ncol(city_dfts) + 1):ncol(pm3$data$component_true)]   ),   "farima7" = as.numeric(     pm4$data$component_true$data[, (ncol(city_dfts) + 1):ncol(pm4$data$component_true)]   ) )   true <- utils::read.csv(   paste0("C:/Users/jerem/OneDrive/Documents/School/Waterloo/Research/RPackages/fChange/vignettes/articles/pollution_true.txt") )[, 2] res <- colSums((ests_final - true)^2) res / min(res) #  arima   ets    fets  farima  fets_log  farima_log #  1.376  1.601  1.450  1.000   1.866     1.073 mod <- projection_model(city_dfts,   forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = h,   check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F ) mod$plots$forecast_plot

text: One standard way investigate serial dependence time series terms serial correlation. autocovariance operator lag hh, h≥0h \ge 0, defined Γh(x)(t):=∫γh(t,s)x(s)ds,x∈L2[0,1],     \Gamma_h(x)(t) := \int \gamma_h(t, s) x(s) ds, \ \ \ x\L^2[0,1], γh(t,s)\gamma_h(t, s) autocovariance kernel defined γh(t,s):=E[(Xi(t)−μ(t))(Xi+h(s)−μ(s))],t,s∈[0,1].\gamma_h(t,s) :=E [ (X_i(t)-\mu(t))(X_{+h} (s)-\mu(s))],\ \ \ \ t,s \[0,1]. lag zero, Γ0=C\Gamma_0 = C, CC covariance operator . functions γh(⋅,⋅)\gamma_h(\cdot, \cdot), h≥0h\ge 0, characterize serial correlation series {Xi}\{ X_i\}. Given functional observations, X1,…,XTX_1,\ldots, X_T, γh\gamma_h can estimated using sample counterpart γ̂T,h(t,s):=1T∑=1T−h(Xi(t)−X‾T(t))(Xi+h(s)−X‾T(s)),0≤h<T.\hat\gamma_{T,h}(t,s):=\frac{1}{T}\sum_{=1}^{T-h} (X_i(t)-\bar{X}_T(t))(X_{+h}(s)-\bar{X}_T(s)), \ \ \ 0 \le h < T. simple graphical summary serial dependence series can obtained plotting ρ̂h=∥γ̂T,h∥2∫γ̂T,0(t,t)dt\begin{aligned} \hat{\rho}_h =\frac{\|\hat{\gamma}_{T,h}\|_2}{\int \hat{\gamma}_{T,0}(t,t)dt} \end{aligned} function hh, refer functional autocorrelation function (fACF). coefficient ρ̂h\hat\rho_h scale-free measure satisfying 0≤ρ̂h≤10 \le \hat\rho_h \le 1, quantifies strength serial correlation series. function-valued white noise, expect autocorrelations nonzero lag close zero. function acf() applied dfts object plots fACF function hh, h=1,…,Hh = 1, \ldots, H. default, function plots 95%95\% confidence bounds autocorrelation assuming series forms strong white noise, well confidence bounds assuming series drawn general function-valued weak white noise process serially uncorrelated. latter bounds preferable evaluating serial dependence FTS potentially exhibiting volatility (conditional heteroscedasticity), example derived high-frequency asset prices. robust graphical summary serial dependence FTS functional spherical autocorrelation function (fSACF). fSACF lag hh computed average inner product lagged pairs series XiX_i Xi+hX_{+h} centered: ρ̃h=1T∑=1T−h⟨Xi−μ̃∥Xi−μ̃∥,Xi+h−μ̃∥Xi+h−μ̃∥⟩,0≤h<T,\tilde\rho_h=\frac{1}{T}\sum_{=1}^{T-h} \langle \frac{X_i - \tilde{\mu}}{\|X_i - \tilde{\mu}\|}, \frac{X_{+h} - \tilde{\mu}}{\|X_{+h} - \tilde{\mu}\|} \rangle,\ \ \ \ 0 \le h < T, μ̃\tilde{\mu} estimated spatial median series. range measure −1≤ρ̃h≤1-1 \le \tilde{\rho}_h \le 1. fSACF provides advantages fACF : 1) captures magnitude also direction serial correlation series, 2) robust outliers. See function sacf(). First consider Brownian motion known signal given . text: Since many procedures analyze FTS assume level data stationary, useful methods evaluate plausibility assumption. Moreover, many cases evident departures stationarity appear due shocks “structural changes" data generating mechanism. ”change points" can independent interest, might alter models use FTS light detecting estimating locations changes. methods used latter task fall umbrella change point analysis. Test statistics stationarity change point detection often rely functional partial sum process, ST(x,t)=1T∑=1⌊Tx⌋Xi(t)\begin{aligned}     S_T(x,t) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{T}} \sum_{=1}^{\lfloor T x\rfloor} X_i(t) \end{aligned} x∈[0,1]x\[0,1] termed “partial sample parameter". Note ST(1,t)=TX‾TS_T(1,t) = \sqrt{T}\bar{X}_T. can used define cumulative sum (CUSUM) process ZT(x,t)=ST(x,t)−xST(1,t).\begin{aligned}     Z_T(x, t) = S_T(x,t) - x S_T(1,t)\,. \end{aligned} data non-stationary, CUSUM process tends fluctuate respect partial sample parameter xx data stationary. Natural test statistics based CUSUM process measure magnitude ZTZ_{T} $$\begin{aligned}     I_T = \int_0^1 \hspace{-.1cm} \int_0^1 Z_T^2(x,t) dt\,dx\, , \end{aligned}$$ MT=supx∈[0,1]∫01ZT2(x,t)dt.\begin{aligned}     M_T = \sup_{x \[0,1]} \int_0^1 Z_T^2(x,t) dt. \end{aligned} Methods proposed (Aue, Rice, Sönmez 2018) (Horváth, Kokoszka, Rice 2014) produce p−p-values assessing evidence hypothesis data stationary change points present based statistics. One stationary test implemented stationary_test(). brownian motion non-significant p-value suggesting stationarity tests. Spanish electricity data p-value <0.001<0.001 tests. first difference model residuals return non-significant p-values, suggesting stationarity. Applying change point detection electricity data, two change point observed; see Figures 3.5 and3.6. Since changes suggest regions homogeneity data, CV re-run looking 14 day forecasts order compare previous models models based last homogeneous segment: 1.000 (ets), 1.013 (arima), 1.157 (ets cp), 1.232 (arima cp). Although data last segment appears homogeneous, case reduction data lead worse CV performance. Try another segmentation see different effect! French mortality, example segmentation forecast given .
code: stationarity_test(data_bm)  stationarity_test(electricity) stationarity_test(elec_ets$data$residuals) stationarity_test(elec_arima$data$residuals)  kpss_test(electricity) kpss_test(elec_ets$data$residuals) kpss_test(elec_arima$data$residuals) set.seed(12345) elec_changes <- fchange(electricity, type = "segmentation") elec_changes$location  plot(electricity,   changes = elec_changes$location,   plot_title = NULL,   eye = list(x = -1, y = -1.5, z = 0.75),   aspectratio = list(x = 0.8, y = 0.6, z = 0.6) ) plot(electricity,   changes = elec_changes$location, type = "change",   plot_title = NULL,   eye = list(x = -1, y = -1.5, z = 0.75),   aspectratio = list(x = 0.8, y = 0.6, z = 0.6) ) # CV pred_idx <- floor(0.8 * ncol(electricity) + 1):(ncol(electricity) - 13) errors <- matrix(NA, nrow = length(pred_idx), ncol = 4) colnames(errors) <- c("fets", "farima", "fetsC", "farimaC")  cp <- 120 # max(elec_changes$location)  cat("CV (", length(pred_idx), "):") for (i in 1:length(pred_idx)) {   cat(i, ", ")   idx <- pred_idx[i]   tmp_dat <- electricity[, 1:(idx - 1)]   tmp_dat$season <- 7   tmp_dat1 <- electricity[, cp:(idx - 1)]   tmp_dat1$season <- 7   tmp_pred <- electricity[idx + 0:6]    pm1 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "ets", n.ahead = 14,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F   )   pm2 <- projection_model(tmp_dat,     forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = 14,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F   )   pm3 <- projection_model(tmp_dat1,     forecast.model = "ets", n.ahead = 14,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F   )   pm4 <- projection_model(tmp_dat1,     forecast.model = "arima", n.ahead = 14,     check.cp = F, sim.bounds = F   )    ests <- data.frame(     "fets" = as.numeric(       pm1$data$component_true$data[, idx + 0:6]     ),     "farima" = as.numeric(       pm2$data$component_true$data[, idx + 0:6]     ),     "fetsC" = as.numeric(       pm3$data$component_true$data[, idx - cp + 1 + 0:6]     ),     "farimaC" = as.numeric(       pm4$data$component_true$data[, idx - cp + 1 + 0:6]     )   )    errors[i, ] <- colSums((ests - as.vector(tmp_pred$data))^2) } colMeans(errors) / min(colMeans(errors)) #   fets   farima  fetsC  farimaC #   1.000  1.013   1.157  1.232 set.seed(123) tmp <- projection_model(fmort, sim.bounds = FALSE, method = "eigenjoint", n.ahead = 20) tmp$plots$forecast_plot

what: Estimate the autocorrelation function of the series — autocorrelation
title: Estimate the autocorrelation function of the series — autocorrelation
text: Obtain empirical autocorrelation function given lags functional time series, X. Given functional time series, sample autocovariance functions \(\hat{C}_{h}(u,v)\) given : $$\hat{C}_{h}(u,v) =  \frac{1}{N} \sum_{=1}^{N-|h|}(X_{}(u) -      \overline{X}_{N}(u))(X_{+|h|}(v) - \overline{X}_{N}(v))$$ \( \overline{X}_{N}(u) = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{= 1}^{N} X_{}(t)\) denotes sample mean function \(h\) lag parameter. autocorrelation functions defined range \((0,1)\) normalizing functions using factor \(\int\hat{C}_{0}(u,u)du\).

title: Estimate the autocorrelation function of the series — autocorrelation
code: autocorrelation(X, lags)

code: fchange(   X,   method = c("characteristic", "mean", "robustmean", "eigenjoint", "eigensingle",     "trace", "covariance", "projmean", "projdistribution"),   statistic = c("Tn", "Mn"),   critical = c("simulation", "resample", "welch"),   type = c("single", "segmentation", "elbow"),   resample_blocks = "separate",   replace = TRUE,   max_changes = min(ncol(X), 20),   changes = NULL,   blocksize = 2 * ncol(X)^(1/5),   eigen_number = 3,   h = 2 * ncol(X)^(1/5),   M = 1000,   J = 50,   W = space_measuring_functions(X = X, M = 20, space = "BM"),   K = bartlett_kernel,   alpha = 0.05,   cov.res = 30,   weighting = 1/4,   TVE = 0.95,   trim_function = function(X) {      0  },   errors = "L2",   recommendation_change_points = 2,   recommendation_improvement = 0.15,   silent.binary = FALSE,   ... )

title: Change Point Detection — fchange
text: X dfts object data can automatically converted format. See dfts(). method Method compute change point. Options include: 'characteristic', 'mean', 'robustmean', 'eigenjoint', 'eigensingle', 'trace', 'covariance', 'projmean', 'projdistribution'. statistic String test statistic type: integrated, Tn, supremum, Mn. critical String method computing threshold. Options 'simulation', 'resample', 'welch'. ways compute critical thresholds implemented every method. type String type change point detection, single change ('single'), binary segmentation ('segmentation'), elbow plots ('elbow'). resample_blocks String indicating type resample test use. Using separate gives blocks separate overlapping creates overlapping sliding windows. blocksize=1 identical. replace Boolean using permutation bootstrapped statistic critical='resample'. max_changes Integer max number changes search using type elbow. changes Vector change points given eigen test data centered values first. blocksize Integer width blocks using resampling test. Can use adaptive_bandwidth() additional guidance desired. eigen_number eigenvalue number eigenvalues checked eigenvalue tests. h Number lags used computing long run covariance estimates. Used mean, characteristic, eigenvalue tests. M Number simulations permutations critical values J Resolution (J) characteristic method. number vectors defined W. W Space measuring functions used characteristic method explore functional space. K Kernel function use characteristic, mean, eigen, covariance projmean. alpha Significance [0,1] Welch approximation. cov.res Resolution use computing covariance kernel changes. weighting Weights used covariance kernel method pcadistribution. TVE Total variance explained projmean projdistribution. trim_function Trimming used multiple change methods. errors Type errors used elbow plot. Options L2 Trace. recommendation_change_points Number lags forward examine deciding automated elbow plot recommendation. recommendation_improvement Significant drop look deciding automated elbow plot recommendation. silent.binary Boolean output printed running binary segmentation. ... Unused additional parameters.

title: Kernel Functions — kernels
text: assortment (vectorized) kernel functions located package. Truncated Kernel: Kernel \(1, |x|\leq 1\) \(0\) otherwise. \(x=0/0\) value \(1\) given. Bartlett Kernel: Kernel \(max(0,1-|x|), h\neq 0\). \(x=0/0\) value \(1\) given. Parzen Kernel: Kernel \(1 - 6 * x^2 + 6 * |x|^3, |x|<=0.5\), \( 2 * (1 - |x|)^3, 0.5<|x|<1\), \(0, |x|>1\). \(x=0/0\) value \(1\) given. Tukey-Hanning Kernel: Kernel \((1 + cos(\pi x) )/2, |x|<=1\) \(0, |x|>1\). \(x=0/0\) value \(1\) given. Quadratic Spectral Kernel: Kernel \(\frac{25}{12\pi^2x^2} \left(\frac{sin(6\pi x/5)}{6\pi x/5} - cos(6\pi x/5) \right)\). \(x=0/0\) value \(1\) given. Daniell Kernel: Kernel \(sin(pi * x) / (pi * x)*(1 + cos(pi*x)), abs(x)<=1\). \(x=0/0\) value \(1\) given. Flat-Top Kernel: Kernel \(min(1, max(1.1-|x|,0)),|x|\leq 1\). \(x=0/0\) value \(1\) given.

what: Functional Hypothesis Tests for Functional Data — portmanteau_tests
title: Functional Hypothesis Tests for Functional Data — portmanteau_tests
text: Computes variety portmanteau hypothesis tests functional data form dfts objects.

title: Functional Hypothesis Tests for Functional Data — portmanteau_tests
code: portmanteau_tests(   X,   test = c("variety", "single", "multi", "spectral", "independence", "imhof"),   lag = 5,   M = 1000,   method = c("iid", "bootstrap"),   kernel = bartlett_kernel,   block_size = NULL,   bandwidth = NULL,   components = 3,   resample_blocks = "separate",   replace = FALSE,   alpha = 0.05 )

title: Functional Hypothesis Tests for Functional Data — portmanteau_tests
text: X dfts object data can automatically converted format. See dfts(). test String specifying hypothesis test. Currently available tests : 'variety', 'single-lag', 'multi-lag', 'spectral', 'independence', 'imhof'. lag positive integer specify lag, maximum lag, interest. used "single-lag", "multi-lag", "independence", "imhof" tests. M Numeric specify number Monte-Carlo resampled simulations use limiting distributions. method String indicating method single test, options include: iid: hypothesis test use strong-white noise assumption (instead weak-white noise assumption). resample: hypothesis test evaluated approximating limiting distribution test statistic via (block) resampling process. Additional methods forthcoming. kernel Kernel function spectral test estimation covariance. block_size Numeric specify block size resampling tests. bandwidth Numeric bandwidth covariance estimation. left null, defined \(N^{1 / (2 * \text{KO} + 1)}\) KO order selected kernel. components Number functional principal components use independence test. resample_blocks String indicating type resample test use. Using separate gives blocks separate overlapping creates overlapping sliding windows. blocksize=1 identical. replace Boolean using permutation bootstrapped statistic method='resample'. alpha Numeric value significance [0,1].

title: Functional Hypothesis Tests for Functional Data — portmanteau_tests
text: List results dependent test. general, returns pvalue, statistic, simulations/quantile.

title: Functional Hypothesis Tests for Functional Data — portmanteau_tests
text: "single"-lag portmanteau test assesses significance empirical lagged autocovariance operators single lag lag. tests null hypothesis lag-h autocovariance operator equal 0. test designed stationary functional time-series, valid conditional heteroscedasticity conditions. "multi"-lag portmanteau test assesses cumulative significance empirical lagged autocovariance operators, user-selected maximum lag lag. tests null hypothesis first lag-h autocovariance operators, \(h=1,\dots,lag\), equal 0. test designed stationary functional time-series, valid conditional heteroscedasticity conditions. "spectral" portmanteau test measures proximity functional time series white noise. Comparison made constant spectral density operator uncorrelated series. test general white noise series, may hold functional conditionally heteroscedastic assumptions. "independence" portmanteau test measures independence identical distribution based lagged cross-variances dimension reduction using functional principal components analysis. test general white noise series, may hold functional conditionally heteroscedastic assumptions. "imhof" portmanteau test analogue "single-lag" test. "single-lag" test computes limiting distribution test statistic via Welch-Satterthwaite approximation, "imhof" test directly computes coefficients quadratic form normal variables. Hence, test computationally expensive.

title: Functional Hypothesis Tests for Functional Data — portmanteau_tests
text: Kim, M., Kokoszka P., & Rice G. (2023) White noise testing functional time series. Statist. Surv., 17, 119-168, DOI: 10.1214/23-SS143 Characiejus, V., & Rice, G. (2020). general white noise test based kernel lag-window estimates spectral density operator. Econometrics Statistics, 13, 175–196. Kokoszka P., & Rice G., & Shang H.L. (2017). Inference autocovariance functional time series conditional heteroscedasticity. Journal Multivariate Analysis, 162, 32-50. Zhang X. (2016). White noise testing model diagnostic checking functional time series. Journal Econometrics, 194, 76-95. Gabrys R., & Kokoszka P. (2007). Portmanteau Test Independence Functional Observations. Journal American Statistical Association, 102:480, 1338-1348, DOI: 10.1198/016214507000001111. Chen W.W. & Deo R.S. (2004). Power transformations induce normality applications. Journal Royal Statistical Society: Series B (Statistical Methodology), 66, 117-130.

title: Functional Hypothesis Tests for Functional Data — portmanteau_tests
code: b <- generate_brownian_motion(100) res0 <- portmanteau_tests(b, test = "single", lag = 2, M=50) res1 <- portmanteau_tests(b, test = "multi", lag = 2, alpha = 0.01) res2 <- portmanteau_tests(b,   test = "spectral", alpha = 0.1,   kernel = parzen_kernel,   bandwidth = adaptive_bandwidth(b, kernel = parzen_kernel) ) res3 <- portmanteau_tests(b, test = "independence", components = 2, lag = 2) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'quantmod': #>   method            from #>   as.zoo.data.frame zoo

text: function offers graphical summary fSACF functional time series (FTS) across different time lags \(h = 1:H\). also plots \(100 \times (1-\alpha)\%\)  confidence bounds developed strong white noise (SWN) assumption lags \(h = 1:H\).

title: Functional Spherical Autocorrelation Function — sacf

title: Functional Spherical Autocorrelation Function — sacf
text: List sACF values plots

title: Functional Spherical Autocorrelation Function — sacf
text: function computes plots functional spherical autocorrelation coefficients lag \(h\), \(h = 1:H\). fSACF lag \(h\) computed average inner product lagged pairs series \(X_i\) \(X_{+h}\) centered scaled: $$   \tilde\rho_h=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{=1}^{N-h} \langle \frac{X_i - \tilde{\mu}}{\|X_i - \tilde{\mu}\|}, \frac{X_{+h} - \tilde{\mu}}{\|X_{+h} - \tilde{\mu}\|} \rangle,\ \ \ \ 0 \le h < N,  $$ \(\tilde{\mu}\) estimated spatial median series. also computes estimated asymptotic \((1-\alpha)100 \%\) confidence lower upper bounds, SWN assumption.

title: Functional Spherical Autocorrelation Function — sacf
text: Yeh C.K., Rice G., Dubin J.. (2023). Functional spherical autocorrelation: robust estimate autocorrelation functional time series. Electronic Journal Statistics, 17, 650–687.

title: Functional Spherical Autocorrelation Function — sacf
code: sacf(electricity)  sacf(generate_brownian_motion(100))

title: Draw 3D Geoms for ggplot2 — stat_3D
text: mapping Default list aesthetic mappings use plot. specified, must supplied layer added plot. data Default dataset use plot. already data.frame, converted one fortify(). specified, must supplied layer added plot. geom geometric object use display data layer. using stat_*() function construct layer, geom argument can used override default coupling stats geoms. geom argument accepts following: Geom ggproto subclass, example GeomPoint. string naming geom. give geom string, strip function name geom_ prefix. example, use geom_point(), give geom "point". information ways specify geom, see layer geom documentation. position Set position information. Find details ggplot2 function. na.rm Boolean na data removed. show.legend logical. layer included legends? NA, default, includes aesthetics mapped. FALSE never includes, TRUE always includes. can also named logical vector finely select aesthetics display. include legend keys levels, even data exists, use TRUE.  NA, levels shown legend, unobserved levels omitted. inherit.aes FALSE, overrides default aesthetics, rather combining . useful helper functions define data aesthetics inherit behaviour default plot specification. ... Arguments passed layer. Often aesthetics like color = "red" size = 3. Two important ones theta (azimuthal rotation) phi (colatitude rotation) define angle degrees viewing data.

title: Draw 3D Geoms for ggplot2 — stat_3D
text: direct return value, called used ggplot2::ggplot() designing plot.

title: Draw 3D Geoms for ggplot2 — stat_3D
text: Acker D (2024). gg3D: 3D perspective plots ggplot2. R package version 0.0.0.9000.

title: Draw 3D Geoms for ggplot2 — stat_3D
code: dat <- electricity  data_lines <- cbind(data.frame("Time" = dat$fparam), dat$data) %>%   tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = 1 + 1:ncol(dat$data))  colors_plot <- RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(11, "Spectral") colors_plot <- grDevices::colorRampPalette(colors_plot)(ncol(dat$data)) data_lines$color <- rep(colors_plot, nrow(dat$data)) data_lines$name <- as.numeric(data_lines$name)  result <- ggplot2::ggplot(   data_lines,   ggplot2::aes(y = Time, x = name, z = value, color = color) ) +   ggplot2::theme_void() +   stat_3D(theta = 0, phi = 15, geom = "path") +   ggplot2::scale_color_manual(     breaks = data_lines$color,     values = data_lines$color   ) +   ggplot2::guides(color = "none")

title: Functional Stationarity Test — stationarity_test
text: Stationarity test functional time series different methods determining critical values test statistic. Monte Carlo method constructed Horvath et al. (2014), resample-based methods validated literature (use provided option discretion).

title: Functional Stationarity Test — stationarity_test
code: stationarity_test(   X,   statistic = "Tn",   critical = c("simulation", "resample"),   perm_method = "separate",   M = 1000,   blocksize = 2 * ncol(X)^(1/5),   TVE = 1,   replace = TRUE,   return.info = FALSE )

title: Functional Stationarity Test — stationarity_test
text: X dfts object data can automatically converted format. See dfts(). statistic String test statistic. Options integrated (Tn) supremum (Mn). default Tn. critical String method determining critical values. Options simulation resample. Default simulation. perm_method String method resampling. Options separate block resampling overlapping sliding window. Default separate. M Numeric number simulation use determining null distribution. Default 1000. blocksize Numeric blocksize resample test. Default \(2N^{1/5}\). TVE Numeric total variance explained using PCA eigenvalues. Default 1. replace Boolean replacement used resample test. Thus, defines bootstrapped permuted test used. Default TRUE. return.info Boolean information test statistic null distribution returned just p-value (default).

title: Functional Stationarity Test — stationarity_test
text: List following elements: pvalue: p-value stationarity test. statistic: test statistic test. simulations: simulations define null distribution.

title: Functional Stationarity Test — stationarity_test
text: Horvath, L., Kokoszka, P., & Rice, G. (2014). Testing stationarity functional time series. Journal Econometrics, 179(1), 66-82.

title: Functional Stationarity Test — stationarity_test
code: res <- stationarity_test(   generate_brownian_motion(100, v = seq(0, 1, length.out = 20)),   critical = "resample", statistic = "Mn" ) res2 <- stationarity_test(electricity)
